newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Megaworld sees profits rising next 5 yrs.
newsitem.headline: Megaworld sees profits rising next 5 yrs.

text.p: Megaworld Properties and Holdings Inc expects profits to rise by a "minimum" of 50 percent in the next five years, company president and chairman Andrew Tan said on Thursday.

"We see a minimum 50 percent growth in profitability in the next five years. This is a young company, we feel we still have some room to grow," Tan told Reuters before an investors briefing the company was slated to hold Thursday afternoon.
Increased earnings will come from revenues of the company from its middle-income housing and rentals operations, Tan added.
Tan said the company will shed light on rumours circulating that the company and its housing developer subsidiary, Empire East Land Holdings Inc, are suffering financial difficulties.
"We are in a very healthy financial condition. We are doing very well. All these talks are really unfounded," Tan said.
Tan said the company stands pat on its earlier projection that it expects to post 2.8 billion pesos this year. In 1996, the company posted net income of 2.69 billion pesos.
Empire East president Gerardo Garcia on Wednesday told Reuters that he expected 33 percent growth in profits and revenues up to the year 2000.
Garcia denied on Wednesday that the company was facing any financial problems.

Megaworld closed on Thursday 10 centavos lower, or 1.23 percent, to 8.00 pesos while Empire East shed 1.10 pesos, or 12.94 percent, to 7.40 pesos. Both stocks were among the top five most actively traded issues of the day.
